elements.content: The reaction of 5,5′-(1,2-ethynediyl)bis(1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid) (H4EBDC) and dinuclear lanthanide building blocks generates five new three-dimensional lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) with different topologies under mild conditions. Isomorphic compounds |C2H7N|[Ln2(EBDC)(NO3)2(C3H7NO)4] [Ln = Eu (1), Tb (2), or Er (3)] crystallize in monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c and adopt PtS topology. Under modified conditions, new phases |(NO3)0.5(H3O)0.5|[Yb2(EBDC)(NO3)2(C3H7NO)4] (space group C2/c, compound 4) and |(H3O)2(C3H7NO)2.5|[Eu2(EBDC)2(C3H7NO)(H2O)] (space group P21/c, compound 5) are obtained. In 4, both of the inorganic and organic building blocks can be simplified into a four-coordinate node, forming an Lvt topological network. For compound 5, the dinuclear Ln unit works as an 8-connected node and the organic ligand serves as a 4-connected node; these two kinds of nodes connect and then present an unprecedented (4,8)-connected topology. The aforementioned Ln-MOFs are all characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis, and their luminescent properties have been studied, showing emission characteristic of inorganic species at room temperature.

elements.content: A variety of lanthanide dinuclear metal centers simplified into different inorganic building units assemble with a multifunctional ligand H4EBDC to produce five novel coordination polymers with PtS, Lvt, and new topology networks. The luminescent properties indicate that the H4EBDC ligand not only could sensitize some UV−vis emissive metal centers via the antenna effect but also could be a suitable organic linker for sensitizing some near-infrared emissive metal center.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), an important class of porous materials, have been widely explored in recent years because of their fascinating structures and their potential applications in gas adsorption and separation, magnetism, catalysis, molecular recognition, etc. Compared to MOFs based on the transition metal sources, Ln-MOFs are less porous because of the high coordination numbers of the lanthanide ions and favor the formation of condensed structures. However, with unique physical and chemical properties, lanthanide ions have been used to construct MOFs with structural flexibility and magnetic and luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), an important class of porous materials, have been widely explored in recent years because of their fascinating structures and their potential applications in gas adsorption and separation, magnetism, catalysis, molecular recognition, etc. Compared to MOFs based on the transition metal sources, Ln-MOFs are less porous because of the high coordination numbers of the lanthanide ions and favor the formation of condensed structures. However, with unique physical and chemical properties, lanthanide ions have been used to construct MOFs with structural flexibility and magnetic and luminescent properties.

elements.content: As the ions suffer from weak light adsorption because of the forbidden f–f transitions, direct excitation of the metals is inefficient. Introducing a strong absorbing linker to connect the lanthanide ions is a common way of overcoming this problem. This coupling would lead a large increase in the luminescent intensity and is widely known as the “antenna effect”. In light of this relationship, selecting and designing suitable organic ligands to be the antenna is greatly important to the luminescent properties of the resulting Ln-MOFs. According to the principle of hard and soft acids and bases (HSAB), the lanthanide ions as hard acids have a high affinity for hard donor atoms (such as oxygen), so that multiple carboxylate ligands would be good choices for the construction of Ln-MOFs. However, it is worth noting that the resultant frameworks are always affected by many experimental parameters, such as the solvent, template, pH, temperature, and metal:ligand stoichiometry; this means that the rational design and synthesis of Ln-MOFs is a greatly challenging task. Our group has been exploring alkyne-functionalized tetracarboxylate ligands and using them to construct new MOFs with fascinating properties. 5,5′-(1,2-Ethynediyl)bis(1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid) (H4EBDC), as a multi-carboxylate ligand, proved to be a suitable organic linker for sensitizing Eu3+ or Tb3+ via the antenna effect in our previous work. Though the H4EBDC ligand was also used by other groups to construct MOFs, it is worth noting that three-dimensional (3D) Ln-MOFs based on the H4EBDC ligand have not been explored. As a continuation of our work, herein, we report five 3D Ln-MOFs by using the H4EBDC ligand. All of the compounds are constructed with a dinuclear metal center and four connected organic ligands. With changes in the synthesis conditions, the structures present different topologies. Compounds 1–3 exhibit PtS topologies; compound 4 displays an Lvt topology, and compound 5 presents an unprecedented (4,8)-connected topology. Among them, H4EBDC ligands show two different coordination modes (coplanar and tetrahedral). The effects of synthesis conditions on the compounds are discussed; the details of the structures and thermal analyses are illustrated, and the luminescent properties of the synthesized compounds are explored.

elements.content: The H4EBDC ligand was prepared according to a literature method. All the other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 400–4000 cm–1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a TGA Q500 V20.10 Build 36 thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range of 35–700 °C under an air flow with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The luminescence spectra were recorded on a JASCO FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter (solid).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The H4EBDC ligand was prepared according to a literature method. All the other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 400-4000 cm-1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a TGA Q500 V20.10 Build 36 thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range of 35-700 °C under an air flow with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The luminescence spectra were recorded on a JASCO FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter (solid).

elements.content: Ln(NO3)3·6H2O [Ln = Eu (1), Tb (2), or Er (3); 0.090 mmol], H4EBDC (0.028 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL), CH3CN (1 mL), and HNO3 (0.2 mL, 2.7 M in DMF) were added to a 20 mL vial, and the solution was heated to 85 °C for 48 h to give colorless crystals (60, 68, and 61% yields based on H4EBDC, respectively). The agreement between the experimental and simulated PXRD patterns indicated the phase purity of the as-synthesized product (see Figure S1 of the ). Analysis for 1. elements.content: Suitable single crystals of compounds 1–5 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The intensity data of compound 4 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID IP diffractometer and a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer for the others using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Data processing was accomplished with the RAPID AUTO processing program for compound 4 and the SAINT processing program for the other compounds. The structures were all determined by direct methods and refined by a full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 using SHELXTL version 5.1. All the metal atoms were located first, and then the oxygen and carbon of the compounds were subsequently found in difference Fourier maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand and water molecules were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors or by geometrical restraints. It is noted that some hydrogen atoms were not added in compounds, as the carbon atoms in a coordinated DMF molecule are disordered. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for all the compounds are summarized in Table .

The single-crystal structural analysis confirms that compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The framework of 1 consists of one crystallographically independent Eu atom, one EBDC4– ligand, one coordinated nitrate ion, and two coordinated DMF molecules. As shown in Figure S3a of the , each Eu(III) ion is eight-coordinated with eight oxygens from four different EBDC4– ligands, two terminally coordinated DMF molecules, and one nitrate ion. The O–Eu bond lengths are in the range of 2.353(4)–2.530(5) Å (Table S1 of the ), all of which are similar to those reported for other Eu(III) ion compounds. In structure 1, four carboxylate groups bridge two Eu(III) ions to form a dinuclear Eu2(CO2)4 distorted paddle-wheel unit with the four carboxylate groups surrounding the Eu–Eu axis (Figure a). The carboxylate oxygen atoms of the H4EBDC ligand adopt bis-monodentate forms and a chelated bidentate coordination mode connected with four dinuclear Eu(III) ions (Scheme S1c of the ), and this leads to the two phenyl planes of each H4EBDC ligand being perpendicular to each other and forming a tetrahedral configuration (Figure b). The inorganic building unit Eu2(CO2)4 and the ligand alternately connect to form a 3D framework (Figure c). The resultant framework possesses rectangular channels with dimensions of 9.4 Å × 13.2 Å along the c axis and 7.6 Å × 8.9 Å along the b axis (Figure S3b,c of the ). To improve our understanding of the framework topology, the Eu2(CO2)4 unit can be seen as a square-planar 4-connected node, and the EBDC4– ligand can be regarded as a tetrahedral 4-connected node (Figure d); finally, compound 1 can be simplified as a (4,4)-connected network (Figure e and Figure S3d of the ). The assembly of these two types of nodes results in the generation of a 3D network with PtS topology (Figure f). The structures of compounds 2 and 3 are similar to that of compound 1, and the Ln(III)–O bond distance are seen to vary with the radii of Ln(III) as shown in Table S1 of the .

elements.content: Complex 4 also crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c, and there are one crystallographically independent Yb atom, one EBDC4– ligand, one coordinated nitrate ion, and two coordinated DMF molecules. As shown in Figure S4a of the , Yb(III) is eight-coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from three carboxyl groups (O1–O4), two coordinated DMF molecules (O5 and O6), and one nitrate ion (O7, O8, and N3). The O–Yb bond lengths are in the range of 2.206(5)–2.431(7) Å. All of them are consistent with the reported Ln-MOFs. In structure 4, two carboxylate groups bridge two Yb(III) ions to form a dinuclear metal center with a Yb–Yb distance of ∼5.259 Å (Figure a). The EBDC4– ligand, with the two phenyl groups in the same plane (Figure b), adopts bis-monodentate and chelated bidentate coordination modes and connects four dinuclear metal centers to form a 3D framework (Figure c). The resultant structure possesses two rhombic channels with dimensions of 10.2 Å × 8.2 Å along the b axis and 8.2 Å × 8.2 Å along the c axis (Figure S4b,c of the ). Topologically, the dinuclear metal center coordinates with four EBDC4– ligand can been regarded as a 4-connected nodes; the EBDC4– ligand can been simplified into a planar 4-connected node (Figure d), and finally, these two nodes alter the link to generate a (4,4)-connected network (Figure e and Figure S4d of the ). The structure displays short and long Schläfli symbols of 42·84 and 4·4·84·84·88·88, respectively. Although it has the same circuit symbol to PtS net, the topology is quite different, and this topological type was classified and described as Lvt (Figure f).

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The framework is constructed by two crystallographically independent Eu atoms, two organic ligands, one coordinated DMF molecule, and one terminal water molecule. Figure S5 of the presents the coordination characteristics of Eu1 and Eu2. Eu1 is nine-coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from five different EBDC4– ligands; the remaining one is from a water molecule. Eu2 is eight-coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from EBDC4– ligands and one DMF molecule. The Eu–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.277(5)–2.606(5) Å, all of which are similar to previously reported Eu–O bond lengths. In compound 5, the EBDC4– ligand exhibits two orientations, and the dihedral angle between the two oriented EBDC4– molecules is ∼65.3°. Two Eu(III) ions coordinated with two EBDC4– ligands to form a dinuclear metal center, Eu2(CO2)4, and then the Eu2(CO2)4 linked with the EBDC4– ligand, resulting in a unique two-dimensional (2D) layer along the a–c plane (Figure a,b). The distance between adjacent layers is ∼8.5 Å; therefore, the EBDC4– ligand acts as a pillar to connect the structure to the 3D framework (Figure c). To improve our understanding of the framework topology, the dinuclear Eu(III) units that connect with eight organic ligands can be simplified into hexagonal bipyramidal 8-connected nodes, and the organic ligand serves as a planar 4-connected node (Figure d); therefore, these two kinds of nodes alter the connection and then present an unprecedented (4,8)-connected topology (Figure e). The framework can be described as a 3-nodal network with a Schläfli symbol of [412·616][44·62][45·6] and a stoichiometry of (4-c)2(8-c) (Figure f).

Crystal Structure of |(H3O)2(C3H7NO)2.5|[Eu2(EBDC)2(C3H7NO)(H2O)] (5)

Compound 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The framework is constructed by two crystallographically independent Eu atoms, two organic ligands, one coordinated DMF molecule, and one terminal water molecule. Figure S5 of the  presents the coordination characteristics of Eu1 and Eu2. Eu1 is nine-coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from five different EBDC4- ligands; the remaining one is from a water molecule. Eu2 is eight-coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from EBDC4- ligands and one DMF molecule. The Eu-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.277(5)-2.606(5) Å, all of which are similar to previously reported Eu-O bond lengths. In compound 5, the EBDC4- ligand exhibits two orientations, and the dihedral angle between the two oriented EBDC4- molecules is ~65.3°. Two Eu(III) ions coordinated with two EBDC4- ligands to form a dinuclear metal center, Eu2(CO2)4, and then the Eu2(CO2)4 linked with the EBDC4- ligand, resulting in a unique two-dimensional (2D) layer along the a-c plane (Figure a,b). The distance between adjacent layers is ~8.5 Å; therefore, the EBDC4- ligand acts as a pillar to connect the structure to the 3D framework (Figure c). To improve our understanding of the framework topology, the dinuclear Eu(III) units that connect with eight organic ligands can be simplified into hexagonal bipyramidal 8-connected nodes, and the organic ligand serves as a planar 4-connected node (Figure d); therefore, these two kinds of nodes alter the connection and then present an unprecedented (4,8)-connected topology (Figure e). The framework can be described as a 3-nodal network with a Schläfli symbol of [412⋅616][44⋅62][45⋅6] and a stoichiometry of (4-c)2(8-c) (Figure f).

elements.content: Although the synthesized Ln-MOF compounds exhibited channels and the channels are larger than N2 molecules, the activated compounds do not exhibit gas adsorption properties. It should contribute to the DMF molecules occupied in the channels. The coordinated DMF molecules cannot be removed at lower temperatures, while at higher temperatures, the framework of the compounds would collapse when DMF were removed.

elements.content: It is well-known that experimental synthesis parameters such as solvent, template, pH, temperature, and metal:ligand stoichiometry in the initial reaction would affect structures or the quality of the final products. Scheme S1 of the presents the reported coordination modes of Ln-MOFs based on the H4EBDC ligand, and Scheme S2 of the shows most of our synthesized compounds. All the exhibited compounds were prepared under mild conditions. When the temperature was ∼85 °C and the metal:ligand ratio was ∼1:1, the final structure of the compound was determined by the kind of solvent. Compounds with the formula [Ln2(EBDC)(NO3)2(C3H7NO)5(Guest)] (Ln = Eu, Tb, or Sm) (Table S2 of the ) were obtained by utilizing pure DMF as the solution, and these compounds exhibited Sql topology with a (4,4)-connected network, which are isostructural to the reported MOFs. As the solvent was changed to DMA and a mixed H2O solvent, the compound transformed to the Kgd topology with a (3,6)-connected network (Table S2 of the ). When DMF and H2O were used as the mixed solvent, needle-shaped crystals were obtained. However, the crystals are too small to be selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. To obtain perfect crystals for characterization, the reaction conditions were slighty changed via the addition of more acid and the introduction of a small amount of morpholine; surprisingly, compound 5 with a new topology was obtained. For further investigation, the metal:ligand ratio was changed to be 3:1, and three more compounds with PtS, Lvt, and NbO topologies were synthesized. Because the compound with NbO topology is unstable, only basic information was obtained as shown in Figure S6 of the . From a topological perspective, although these topological compounds are all part of a (4,4)-connected 3D network, the tiling is different. As shown in Scheme S3 of the , the tilings for the PtS net are 42·82 and 84, the tiling for the Lvt net is 42·84, and the tiling for the NbO net is 64·82. These three compounds were obtained from similar synthesis conditions. Compared to the PtS compounds, the compound with Lvt topology was obtained by adding a small amount of morpholine, which indicates that morpholine may be a template to affect the final structure. The difference in the conditions between Lvt and NbO topologies is the amount of HNO3; this means that the NbO compound was obtained by reducing the volume of HNO3 to 0.1 mL, but the compound has poor repeatability. As far as we know, this is the first example of simultaneously synthesizing PtS, Lvt, and NbO topologies by using lanthanide with the same ligand. On the basis of this fact, some inspiration was found. (1) Lanthanide ions could coordinate with the H4EBDC ligand and be highly crystalline under mild conditions when the reaction temperature was ∼85 °C, which is lower than most temperatures of other reported synthesis conditions of Ln-MOFs. (2) The solvent plays an important role in constructing diverse structures. As shown in Table S3 of the , a slight change in solvent would give rise to a different polarity, and it contributes to the ligand seeking the suitable solubility to construct diverse topological compounds. As a result of the influence of polarity, DMF as the participator is indispensable in assembling the frameworks, and acetonitrile used in the reaction is necessary for the synthesis of PtS and Lvt compounds but absent in the product; this indicates that the coordination environment may be impacted by the solvent molecules that act as structure-directing agents. In addition, morpholine as the template may affect the geometric configuration of the ligand from the tetrahedron to the plane, leading to the formation of two different topological compounds. Water as the second solvent, being smaller, is more competitive as the terminal coordinated molecule than DMF or NO3 –; water promotes the formation of compound 5. Therefore, different topological compounds were synthesized in this paper by changing the types of solvents. (3) Although we found that the transition metal:ligand ratio in the original reaction has no effect on the final structure, it is obvious that by using lanthanide as the metal source, different metal:ligand stoichiometries would result in distinct structures.

Synthesis

It is well-known that experimental synthesis parameters such as solvent, template, pH, temperature, and metal:ligand stoichiometry in the initial reaction would affect structures or the quality of the final products. Scheme S1 of the  presents the reported coordination modes of Ln-MOFs based on the H4EBDC ligand, and Scheme S2 of the  shows most of our synthesized compounds. All the exhibited compounds were prepared under mild conditions. When the temperature was ~85 °C and the metal:ligand ratio was ~1:1, the final structure of the compound was determined by the kind of solvent. Compounds with the formula [Ln2(EBDC)(NO3)2(C3H7NO)5(Guest)] (Ln = Eu, Tb, or Sm) (Table S2 of the ) were obtained by utilizing pure DMF as the solution, and these compounds exhibited Sql topology with a (4,4)-connected network, which are isostructural to the reported MOFs. As the solvent was changed to DMA and a mixed H2O solvent, the compound transformed to the Kgd topology with a (3,6)-connected network (Table S2 of the ). When DMF and H2O were used as the mixed solvent, needle-shaped crystals were obtained. However, the crystals are too small to be selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. To obtain perfect crystals for characterization, the reaction conditions were slighty changed via the addition of more acid and the introduction of a small amount of morpholine; surprisingly, compound 5 with a new topology was obtained. For further investigation, the metal:ligand ratio was changed to be 3:1, and three more compounds with PtS, Lvt, and NbO topologies were synthesized. Because the compound with NbO topology is unstable, only basic information was obtained as shown in Figure S6 of the . From a topological perspective, although these topological compounds are all part of a (4,4)-connected 3D network, the tiling is different. As shown in Scheme S3 of the , the tilings for the PtS net are 42⋅82 and 84, the tiling for the Lvt net is 42⋅84, and the tiling for the NbO net is 64⋅82. These three compounds were obtained from similar synthesis conditions. Compared to the PtS compounds, the compound with Lvt topology was obtained by adding a small amount of morpholine, which indicates that morpholine may be a template to affect the final structure. The difference in the conditions between Lvt and NbO topologies is the amount of HNO3; this means that the NbO compound was obtained by reducing the volume of HNO3 to 0.1 mL, but the compound has poor repeatability. As far as we know, this is the first example of simultaneously synthesizing PtS, Lvt, and NbO topologies by using lanthanide with the same ligand. On the basis of this fact, some inspiration was found. (1) Lanthanide ions could coordinate with the H4EBDC ligand and be highly crystalline under mild conditions when the reaction temperature was ~85 °C, which is lower than most temperatures of other reported synthesis conditions of Ln-MOFs. (2) The solvent plays an important role in constructing diverse structures. As shown in Table S3 of the , a slight change in solvent would give rise to a different polarity, and it contributes to the ligand seeking the suitable solubility to construct diverse topological compounds. As a result of the influence of polarity, DMF as the participator is indispensable in assembling the frameworks, and acetonitrile used in the reaction is necessary for the synthesis of PtS and Lvt compounds but absent in the product; this indicates that the coordination environment may be impacted by the solvent molecules that act as structure-directing agents. In addition, morpholine as the template may affect the geometric configuration of the ligand from the tetrahedron to the plane, leading to the formation of two different topological compounds. Water as the second solvent, being smaller, is more competitive as the terminal coordinated molecule than DMF or NO3 -; water promotes the formation of compound 5. Therefore, different topological compounds were synthesized in this paper by changing the types of solvents. (3) Although we found that the transition metal:ligand ratio in the original reaction has no effect on the final structure, it is obvious that by using lanthanide as the metal source, different metal:ligand stoichiometries would result in distinct structures.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on crystalline samples under an atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C. TGA indicated that compounds 1–3 display similar thermal performance because of their isomorphous structures, and compounds 1–5 all exhibit high thermal stability as shown in Figure S7 of the . Therefore, only the thermal stabilities of compounds 1, 4, and 5 are discussed in detail. For compound 1, the TG curve shows the first mass loss of 4.21% below 100 °C due to the release of one guest dimethylamine molecule that comes from the decomposition of DMF molecules (calcd, 4.01%). A further weight loss of 36.04% between 100 and 450 °C should be attributed to the coordinated DMF molecules and nitrate ions (calcd, 37.32%), and then the sharp weight loss of 24.23% from 450 to 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the ligand; the final product is confirmed to be a main phase of Eu2O3 (JCPDS Card 34-0392), TbO x , or Er2O3 (JCPDS Card 08-0050) by PXRD. Compound 4 shows a continuous weight loss (39.71%) from the beginning to 500 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of the coordinated DMF molecules and nitric ions, as well as the guest molecules (calcd, 39.61%), and then the sharp weight loss (26.70%) between 500 and 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand (calcd, 26.19%); the postresidue value of 33.59% is for Yb2O3 (JCPDS Card 41-1106). For compound 5, the first continuous 31.75% weight loss (calcd, 31.32%) below 380 °C was due to the release of guest molecules, coordinated DMF and water molecules, and then the sharp weight loss (44.40%) between 400 and 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand (calcd, 44.85%); the final product is confirmed to be a main phase of Eu2O3 (JCPDS Card 34-0392) by PXRD.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on crystalline samples under an atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C. TGA indicated that compounds 1-3 display similar thermal performance because of their isomorphous structures, and compounds 1-5 all exhibit high thermal stability as shown in Figure S7 of the . Therefore, only the thermal stabilities of compounds 1, 4, and 5 are discussed in detail. For compound 1, the TG curve shows the first mass loss of 4.21% below 100 °C due to the release of one guest dimethylamine molecule that comes from the decomposition of DMF molecules (calcd, 4.01%). A further weight loss of 36.04% between 100 and 450 °C should be attributed to the coordinated DMF molecules and nitrate ions (calcd, 37.32%), and then the sharp weight loss of 24.23% from 450 to 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the ligand; the final product is confirmed to be a main phase of Eu2O3 (JCPDS Card 34-0392), TbO x , or Er2O3 (JCPDS Card 08-0050) by PXRD. Compound 4 shows a continuous weight loss (39.71%) from the beginning to 500 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of the coordinated DMF molecules and nitric ions, as well as the guest molecules (calcd, 39.61%), and then the sharp weight loss (26.70%) between 500 and 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand (calcd, 26.19%); the postresidue value of 33.59% is for Yb2O3 (JCPDS Card 41-1106). For compound 5, the first continuous 31.75% weight loss (calcd, 31.32%) below 380 °C was due to the release of guest molecules, coordinated DMF and water molecules, and then the sharp weight loss (44.40%) between 400 and 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand (calcd, 44.85%); the final product is confirmed to be a main phase of Eu2O3 (JCPDS Card 34-0392) by PXRD.

elements.content: The H4EBDC ligand proved to be an excellent organic linker for sensitizing Eu3+ or Tb3+ via the antenna effect in our previous work. As shown in Figure , the fluorescence of the ligand at room temperature exhibits a broad emission band between 460 and 500 nm with an emission maximum at 488 nm (excitation at 392 nm, the excitation maximum). The solid state photoluminescence spectra of compounds 1–5 were also recorded at room temperature. For compounds 1, 2, and 5, the main intraligand band is suppressed followed by the appearance of the characteristic 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) emission bands for Eu3+ compounds and 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 3, 4, 5, and 6) emission bands for the Tb3+ compound. From the spectra, the ligand-based emission that is not observed indicates that the surrounding ligands absorb and subsequently transfer energy efficiently to the central metal ions. Excitation of Eu compounds leads to a sharp emission peak arising from transitions between the 5D0 → 7FJ crystal-field components (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) with five prominent emission peaks at 586, 592, 618, 650, and 700 nm in the emission spectrum. The emission spectrum shows two main peaks around 592 nm (5D0 → 7F1) and 618 nm (5D0 → 7F2) that correspond to the orange-red and red colors, respectively. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition for the Eu-MOFs corresponds to a magnetic dipole transition that is largely independent of the local environment of the Eu3+ ion. The most intense emission in the luminescent spectra around 618 nm is ascribed to the electric dipolar 5D0 → 7F2 transition, which is responsible for the red emission observed for these MOFs.

elements.content: From the emission spectrum, compound 1 is different from 5 in terms of its splitting peak, and it is interesting to observe that the emission spectra could provide information about the structural difference in their coordination sites. The splitting emission band for the 5D0 → 7F2 transition indicates that there is only one type of coordination environment for the Eu3+ cation in 1, and the absent splitting for the 5D0 → 7F2 transition indicates that there are at least two different types of Eu3+ species in 5. The results are in good agreement with the single-crystal X-ray analyses.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized five Ln-MOFs by utilizing a rigid tetracarboxylate ligand with an extended π-system based on isophthalate moieties connected by alkyne functionalities. Compounds 1–5 with a 3D network exhibit higher thermal stabilities. Compounds 1–3 with the isomorphous structures display PtS topologies that yield 4-connected dinuclear metal center nodes and 4-connected organic ligand nodes. Compound 4 based on a (4,4)-connected node possesses Lvt topology, and compound 5 presents a new topology with a (4,8)-connected node. The luminescence investigations reveal that all of the compounds display strong emission peaks characteristic of inorganic species, and the results indicate that the H4EBDC ligand not only could sensitize some UV–vis emissive metal centers via the antenna effect but also could be a suitable organic linker for sensitizing some near-IR emissive metal center; such effects might have some potential applications in sensing and optics.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized five Ln-MOFs by utilizing a rigid tetracarboxylate ligand with an extended π-system based on isophthalate moieties connected by alkyne functionalities. Compounds 1-5 with a 3D network exhibit higher thermal stabilities. Compounds 1-3 with the isomorphous structures display PtS topologies that yield 4-connected dinuclear metal center nodes and 4-connected organic ligand nodes. Compound 4 based on a (4,4)-connected node possesses Lvt topology, and compound 5 presents a new topology with a (4,8)-connected node. The luminescence investigations reveal that all of the compounds display strong emission peaks characteristic of inorganic species, and the results indicate that the H4EBDC ligand not only could sensitize some UV-vis emissive metal centers via the antenna effect but also could be a suitable organic linker for sensitizing some near-IR emissive metal center; such effects might have some potential applications in sensing and optics.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on crystalline samples under an atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C. TGA indicated that compounds 1-3 display similar thermal performance because of their isomorphous structures, and compounds 1-5 all exhibit high thermal stability as shown in Figure S7 of the . Therefore, only the thermal stabilities of compounds 1, 4, and 5 are discussed in detail. For compound 1, the TG curve shows the first mass loss of 4.21% below 100 °C due to the release of one guest dimethylamine molecule that comes from the decomposition of DMF molecules (calcd, 4.01%). A further weight loss of 36.04% between 100 and 450 °C should be attributed to the coordinated DMF molecules and nitrate ions (calcd, 37.32%), and then the sharp weight loss of 24.23% from 450 to 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the ligand; the final product is confirmed to be a main phase of Eu2O3 (JCPDS Card 34-0392), TbO x , or Er2O3 (JCPDS Card 08-0050) by PXRD. Compound 4 shows a continuous weight loss (39.71%) from the beginning to 500 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of the coordinated DMF molecules and nitric ions, as well as the guest molecules (calcd, 39.61%), and then the sharp weight loss (26.70%) between 500 and 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand (calcd, 26.19%); the postresidue value of 33.59% is for Yb2O3 (JCPDS Card 41-1106). For compound 5, the first continuous 31.75% weight loss (calcd, 31.32%) below 380 °C was due to the release of guest molecules, coordinated DMF and water molecules, and then the sharp weight loss (44.40%) between 400 and 700 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand (calcd, 44.85%); the final product is confirmed to be a main phase of Eu2O3 (JCPDS Card 34-0392) by PXRD.

Luminescent Properties

The H4EBDC ligand proved to be an excellent organic linker for sensitizing Eu3+ or Tb3+ via the antenna effect in our previous work. As shown in Figure , the fluorescence of the ligand at room temperature exhibits a broad emission band between 460 and 500 nm with an emission maximum at 488 nm (excitation at 392 nm, the excitation maximum). The solid state photoluminescence spectra of compounds 1-5 were also recorded at room temperature. For compounds 1, 2, and 5, the main intraligand band is suppressed followed by the appearance of the characteristic 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) emission bands for Eu3+ compounds and 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 3, 4, 5, and 6) emission bands for the Tb3+ compound. From the spectra, the ligand-based emission that is not observed indicates that the surrounding ligands absorb and subsequently transfer energy efficiently to the central metal ions. Excitation of Eu compounds leads to a sharp emission peak arising from transitions between the 5D0 → 7FJ crystal-field components (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) with five prominent emission peaks at 586, 592, 618, 650, and 700 nm in the emission spectrum. The emission spectrum shows two main peaks around 592 nm (5D0 → 7F1) and 618 nm (5D0 → 7F2) that correspond to the orange-red and red colors, respectively. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition for the Eu-MOFs corresponds to a magnetic dipole transition that is largely independent of the local environment of the Eu3+ ion. The most intense emission in the luminescent spectra around 618 nm is ascribed to the electric dipolar 5D0 → 7F2 transition, which is responsible for the red emission observed for these MOFs.
